text: {"grade": 1, "reasoning": "The criterion requires the response to state that the T-shirt with the warped mocking version of the character would be considered a copyright violation as a derivative work (and potentially a right of integrity violation) in Italy. Section 1.E of the candidate answer addresses this directly: 'A \u201cwarped\u201d version mocking a famous joke might be argued as parody, but printing it on commercial T\u2010shirts for sale weighs against the seller...' and 'Bottom line: parody-type defenses exist, but they are not a free pass for unlicensed merchandise, especially when the graphic is recognizably your client\u2019s character and the goal is sales.' This implies that without a successful parody defense, it is an infringement, likely as a derivative work. While it doesn't explicitly use the term 'right of integrity violation,' the discussion of parody/pastiche in the EU context inherently touches upon moral rights, and classifying the unauthorized commercial use of a warped version as infringement covers the core requirement.", "criterion_id": "7fa2efd8-305b-4b3e-b8d7-eddaaba059cd"}
